Posts.Content: last night trolling the internet on prostate nodules, I came across one urologist who asserts that nodules present with infection, may go away as the infection is cleared up, and that the protocol is to wait to see if this happens, rather than jumping to a biopsy. http://www.wmfurology.com/pcaprost_nodule.htm This dials down my thinking from 100% rush to biopsy toward 95%...wondering if I should skip the private clinic urologist and wait for my end of August Urology appointment to see if my little friend is still there. The Canadian GP did say "it is very small". The big metric here is to avoid the risk of the cells migrating outside the walnut, right, and balance this risk against the risks of treatment? At what point, what are the thresholds or triggers... does one press the urgency button and rush into treatment? The psychological side is wanting to roll the dice asap and take the slightly favorable odds of reality ejecting me from this interesting club!
Posts.Signature: Age 56 2009/08 PSA 1.6 2010/08 PSA 1.8 2011/08 PSA 1.9 2012/08 PSA 2.1 2013/03 PSA 5.4 UTI from new bike - 1 cm nodule detected by Florida GP DRE 2013/04 PSA 4.4, nodule confirmed by Florida Urologist, biopsy recommended following infection waiting period 2013/05 PSA 2.6 by Ontario GP - end of August Urologist consult appointment! 2013/06/15 PSA 2.59 - Free:Total ratio 10% (.26/2.59) 2013/06/28 smooth nodule confirmed by Montreal private clinic URO, 14 core Biopsy done that afternoon, following Cipro 2013/07/09 Gleason 6 in 5% of one core, referred to home town URO for monitoring
Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: Got my Free PSA ratio which was alarming.....10%. I think this tips me toward taking the private clinic appointment and getting the biopsy asap. My GP is in a "don't worry be happy" mode focusing on the 2.6 total PSA number, but I am concerned that my knowledge of the subject either now exceeds his and/or he has his foot on the brakes due to pressure on him from how the single payer system works in Ontario. The official lab report says that when total PSA is below 4 "interpretive data is not available" for the free PSA ratio, however I see research that suggests that free PSA is of particular significance when total is below 4, and the Sunnybrook online risk assessment is now giving me a risk of 63% for any kind of cancer and 40% chance of a Gleason greater than 7. Even if the nodule is from infection and could disappear, the risk assessment still has me with significant risk due to this free PSA 10% result, so the possibility of not getting a biopsy, even if the nodule shrinks, seems to be off the table. If I am doing a biopsy anyways, psychological management points me to reaching for the 37% chance that this is benign, sooner rather than later, in a couple of weeks rather than a couple of months.
Posts.Signature: Age 56 2009/08 PSA 1.6 2010/08 PSA 1.8 2011/08 PSA 1.9 2012/08 PSA 2.1 2013/03 PSA 5.4 UTI from new bike - 1 cm nodule detected by Florida GP DRE 2013/04 PSA 4.4, nodule confirmed by Florida Urologist, biopsy recommended following infection waiting period 2013/05 PSA 2.6 by Ontario GP - end of August Urologist consult appointment! 2013/06/15 PSA 2.59 - Free:Total ratio 10% (.26/2.59) 2013/06/28 smooth nodule confirmed by Montreal private clinic URO, 14 core Biopsy done that afternoon, following Cipro 2013/07/09 Gleason 6 in 5% of one core, referred to home town URO for monitoring
Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: Interesting club to be joining here! Got a small nodule that turned up with DRE related to a UTI investigation when I was in Florida. GP was doing PSAs but not DREs for annual physical. Any sort of palpable nodule irrespective of PSA, family history or Free PSA ratio, means I should biopsy asap, right? I need to know if there are cancer cells and what the Gleason Score is, right? I can't locate any protocol that calls for watchful waiting or patience when there is nodule. Otherwise no symptoms, UTI from new bike cleared up. The Ontario system generated a single payer ("free") first consult with a urologist end of August, but for $1000 I can get a consult and biopsy in Montreal in a few weeks. Is my impatience warranted?

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: this is good feedback. I have to be careful to balance individual anecdote with playing the odds rationally. starting to feel like a poker game....is my little nodule friend holding aces or twos? I am being very aggressive with collecting no-risk information. PSAs out the ying yang, free PSA ratio, family history, palpations at the drop of a hat, but then trying to be slightly more cautious about biopsy, which does have slight infection and remote sepsis risk, both fixable, especially for a recent case of prostatitis, and then much much more skeptical regarding treatment. The Free PSA ratio result will dial up or dial down my attitude to this sooner or later biopsy question. Have you guys discussed the SunnyBrook risk assessment tool? http://sunnybrook.ca/content/?page=occ-prostatecalc My current focus is not so much about the risk of an aggressive cancer, it is more about the risk of delay if it is an aggressive cancer and what are the signposts for taking urgent action regarding metrics like nodule size, nodule velocity, PSA level and velocity etc. What are the signs of an imminent escape from the capsule?

Posts.Title: Nodule with Low PSA

Posts.Content: Yeah, my Florida URO would have dialed in to that nodule a month ago, delayed only due to the UTI, and likely would already have the prostate in a jar by now. June 27 consult for sure happen'in and July 9 biopsy, if warranted. Not waiting for the single payer appointment end of August. I doubt this will happen, but what if the uro DREs in and no longer feels the nodule, and dismisses the Free ratio based on the low Total PSA, and objects to doing a biopsy, especially given elevated risk due to my recent UTI? What is the meaning of 10% Free Ratio, (for sure cause for concern when total is elevated), when Total is only 2.6 and falling (and likely closer to 2.2 once the infection distortion is worked through and I extrapolate my baseline velocity of .15 per year)? I read conflicting information. All things considered, after all the reading I have done, I being to wonder if a biopsy is actually something any man should have at my age, regardless of the DRE/PSA risk metrics, and then let the higher metrics of Gleason and cores guide appropriate treatment or WW/AS. You can't have too much information as long as your response to the information is rational and balanced. Reached a dead end on my dad's info with his GP. I think his files were transferred around during his lung cancer treatment and palliative care. As I am doing the biopsy regardless, based on other metrics, I am going to go with my mother's recollection, which is that he "had issues, but no talk of cancer". If need be, I might massage how I communicate this to the system if I think I am being slow walked for assessment or treatment. Once I get my Gleason and cores, I doubt anyone will care about family history.

Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind In the States, noduals, lumps, bumps, roughness observed during a DRE lead directly to a biopsy.. After the biopsy, based on those results, further treatment planning is done...Cash price for a biopsy at a U.S. urology center is around $800. thats about what the private clinic in Montreal charges for any Canucks needing a fast biopsy. My Florida Uro pointed out that it would be better to get it done under the Canadian system in case of complications, though I am not sure what complications could occur for a biopsy within the time window of getting back to Canada. I presume infection and sepsis don't happen overnight, but he was likely considering my status as a snowbird remaining in Florida for another month. Canadians interacting with US health care I suppose is a whole topic.
Posts.Signature: Age 56 2009/08 PSA 1.6 2010/08 PSA 1.8 2011/08 PSA 1.9 2012/08 PSA 2.1 2013/03 PSA 5.4 UTI from new bike - 1 cm nodule detected by Florida GP DRE 2013/04 PSA 4.4, nodule confirmed by Florida Urologist, biopsy recommended following infection waiting period 2013/05 PSA 2.6 by Ontario GP - end of August Urologist consult appointment! 2013/06/15 PSA 2.59 - Free:Total ratio 10% (.26/2.59) 2013/06/28 smooth nodule confirmed by Montreal private clinic URO, 14 core Biopsy done that afternoon, following Cipro 2013/07/09 Gleason 6 in 5% of one core, referred to home town URO for monitoring
Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: Part of this relates to strategies for dealing with single payer system wait times. Based on my alarming low Free ratio (mitigated by a lowish total PSA) in addition to a nodule (mitigated by possible infection cause) I decided to push the accelerator on getting into a private clinic Montreal Uro asap rather than waiting a few months for the single-payer system consult that was offered. Nevertheless, I am keeping the single payer booking as I will need the Montreal result to take to that gatekeeper to get into my city's centralized cancer treatment system if required. Further, I asked to be put on a cancellation list for the local Uro in case an earlier slot opened up. The single payer system and my GP seems to be focused on my low PSA and slow tracking me, nevertheless he cooperated by providing a script for the Montreal clinic as well as the Free PSA bloodwork investigation, so at least he is open to suggestion and cooperating with me guiding my own health decisions. Leaning forward now and preparing myself for a possible non-benign result, and a possible high gleason result, what are the factors to consider when deciding on watchful waiting versus action against the cancer? For the early detection scenario, is there a PSA, Free Ratio, Gleason or other factor threshold, of level or velocity, which says "attack without prejudice!". Putting further pressure, tried to get him to agree to write a script to enable a biopsy based on my paperwork pre-consult, but got pushback as he or his nurse insists on a DRE before charging ahead to a biospy.
Posts.Signature: Age 56 2009/08 PSA 1.6 2010/08 PSA 1.8 2011/08 PSA 1.9 2012/08 PSA 2.1 2013/03 PSA 5.4 UTI from new bike - 1 cm nodule detected by Florida GP DRE 2013/04 PSA 4.4, nodule confirmed by Florida Urologist, biopsy recommended following infection waiting period 2013/05 PSA 2.6 by Ontario GP - end of August Urologist consult appointment! 2013/06/15 PSA 2.59 - Free:Total ratio 10% (.26/2.59) 2013/06/28 smooth nodule confirmed by Montreal private clinic URO, 14 core Biopsy done that afternoon, following Cipro 2013/07/09 Gleason 6 in 5% of one core, referred to home town URO for monitoring

Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: It just occurred to me that if there are a bunch of kooks out there massaging their prostates for entertainment, perhaps there would be a more practical application of this. I assume one would go reach under from the front, rather than around the side. I don't even have the courage to look at the youtubes. Another direction to go in would be to train the girlfriend/spouse to do it, again, following the model of female breast self examination. There are apparently medical things a guy can check for if doing the same for the gal, annally speaking here. Its like when my dental hygenist scans for cancer of the mouth when she is cleaning my teeth. Perhaps way too far in left field here...you could even ask one of the kinky prostate massage parlour people to let you know how your prostate feels, as a screen. Yes, sometimes I carry things too far ; - ) Approaches to problems are always evolving or going through paradigm shifts and change is always controversial, and often comes from unexpected directions. It also occured to me that with what is going on with robotics these days one could construct a mechanical device that would push small rods against the prostate wall from the colon, and very precisely measure the resistance, which would detect any abnormalities. Such a machine would take the same measurement over time and between different persons. A similar machine could be constructed to test for breast lumps. The device would overcome the human resistance to perform and have DREs performed on you, especially lets say in the case of Muslim men, and could be done as an inexpensive technician clinic test. As a general comment about the prostate scene, it strikes me that one should be very aggressive at collecting information through PSEs, DREs, Free Ratio, PCA3s, Biopsies (with closer attention to infection risk mitigation), with the intention of catching things very early, and then applying what science is telling us regarding diet and exercise during the watchful waiting period, with the hope of slowing or even reversing the disease and avoiding the side effects of medical treatment. Beyond this, every man and woman irregardless of detection of cancer or not, should consider themselves to be a pre-cancer patient and pay attention to what the science on diet and exercise is telling us about this disease. There appears to be three key risk areas. 1) A diet that is centered on artificial/processed foods, meat and animal products, which are micro-nutritionally non-dense and calorically dense (The China Study) 2) A diet that elevates and sustains the insulin response to nutritional sugars (glycemic wise), insulin being a growth stimulant for tumors and tumors being blood sugar feeders 3) A physical lifestyle that inhibits the natural healing movement of blood and lymph fluids as well as sleep pathology. Many studies appear to point to dramatic, non-subtle, outcome impacts of changes in the consumption of a single food, such as processed tomatoes by way of example. (for newbies, tomatoes appear to be the only food that is better for you cooked, with no loss of benefit if consuming canned or commercially processed). What if a person layered into their life all of the science-based diet and lifestyle changes indicated by research, well before they enter the prostate risk age window? Logic seems to suggest this, not only in respect of prostate cancer, but as well regarding all cancers and heart disease. I was a few years ago chatting with a very spry 90 year old in a shop on Sanibel, and I have acquired the habit of calibrating the intensity of my attention to the age of the person speaking, and this one fellow told me "all of my friends who spend their retirement days on computers died young".

AgeInfo.Phrase: chatting with a very spry 90 year old in a shop

Posts.Title: Prostate Self DRE

Posts.Content: warning, this is a bit off the beaten track.... After unintentionally stumbling on some sexually related information on prostate stimulation, it occured to me that it must be then possible to do a self DRE, and upon googling this, I came across plenty of information on self DRE'ing, including youtubes. I don't yet have the courage to try this, but it occurred to me that it would be cool if I could feel my nodule myself and take a reading on it once a month. Perhaps someone lacking access to healthcare could try this as the male equivalent of breast self-examination.

Posts.Content: what about this from the American Cancer Society... "The American Cancer Society recommends that men make an informed decision with their doctor about whether to be tested for prostate cancer. Research has not yet proven that the potential benefits of testing outweigh the harms of testing and treatment" http://www.cancer.org/healthy/findca...tion-of-cancer <link approved by Admin> Is there an actual argument in favor of simply ignoring this issue, or are there nuances?

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: Religion, New Age and Spirituality has been a life long interest for me. In the past, when I have had to deal with highly negative situations, I always had a lot of mental and cultural tools to turn to, based on this area of interest. Going through my prostate process here, it has been a good experiment at putting my toolset to work. My current area of reading is what could be called a Science-based "faith" that arises from a study of Quantum Physics, which opens our minds to the measurable strangeness of life, and this coupled with the very hard science related to NDEs, CIA remote viewing, lab measurement of ESP, that sort of thing, which ends up confirming, not negating, much of what religion has tried to communicate poetically. One way to introduce yourself to this way of thinking is by watching any youtube of Thomas Warren Campbell, NASA Physicist (retired). I apologise in advance if this is too weird a thing to be posting. I get into some strange stuff and sometimes lose touch with social appropriateness and context, at least so my wife tells me.

Posts.Title: Management of Emotions for Athiests

Posts.Content: I guess it relates to the broader topic of the mental game and coping mechanisms. Most people are settled in their ways and views, firmly athiest, religious/theist or spiritual, but there are usually a few in any crowd open to exploring new perspectives on things, or even desperately needing a new map for this human experience of living and inevitably dieing. The purpose of the post was to open a door for perhaps one person who might benefit psychologically from this unusual science-based alternative to the usual religious, new age, athiesm choice paradigm. Apart from being an excellent time killer, one of the areas of interest is the science behind the placebo effect and paying attention to that in healing. Another area to explore is the actual evidence for reincarnation and research that has been done under serious professional protocols, which can diminish our conviction that our existence ends at death, reducing fear. As with Pascal's Wager, even if this topic is absolute nonsense, which is a rational beginning presumption, the hypothesis is that it might help manage one's emotional relationship to the disease, which would be a huge benefit and provide a better mental environment for making rational decisions. PS: that's weird, I think Campbell actually lives in Huntsville, your town.

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: I wonder if its like many things in life, where for many, the information will not be processed effectively and the reaction will be mostly emotional, or due to passivity the patient will defer to the doctor who is subject to their own prejudices and conflicts of interest, so at the mean, the cost benefit of testing is a wash, especially when looking backward in time. For the person who researches things to death, comes to forums like this, is very logical and mentally disciplined with making decisions and can control their emotions, will not defer to the authority of the white coats, ...having as much information as possible is beneficial, perhaps very beneficial. Looking forward rather than looking backwards, with newly emerging treatment and technology, I wonder if the cost benefit is dramatically shifting, especially with the latest technology in treatment to minimize side effects and invasiveness of treatment, even if that means a $25k expenditure. So what if the kids have a reduced inheritance or there is lien against the house at probate. That's what money is really for right...a rainy day!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Infection Mitigation

Posts.Content: I had very minimal blood in urine, ejaculate or stool, but I did find that sex in the first couple of weeks seemed to cause soreness the day after, in the prostate, similar to the soreness that I had the first day. My suggestion is that if you have soreness, pay attention to the possibility that it is correlated to sex the previous day. Maybe this was unique to me. Challenging movement with a fullish bladder putting pressure on the healing walls seems to be a no no. A couple days after the biospsy I bent over to frig with the mower, but my bladder was fullish and I was feeling some bladder urgency, and this seemed to trigger one of these soreness attacks for 24 hours. A couple of weeks after the biopsy, yesterday, feeling great, prostate soreness after sex gone, I did some vigorous digging in the garden with a spade. Maybe felt a bit of elevated bladder urgency and even some flow restriction that evening, but then woke up in the middle of the night with returned and elevated prostate soreness, but most alarmingly, nausea, severe weakness, and close to blacking out climbing the stairs to the washroom. No fever. Mild soreness and mild weakness when moving today. No fever. I wonder if with activity I am opening up the wounds between the urinary tract wall and the prostate and it is urine getting into prostate that is causing the soreness. Advil always seems to help. all comments or speculation welcome.

Posts.Content: In addition to meds as directed by my docs, I keep some 100% Cranberry Juice (not the Cranberry Cocktail...not easy to find) and some Pomegranate Juice in the Fridge. I mix these two in a martini/wine glass, the sweetness of the Pomegranate cuts the bitterness of the Cranberry. The cranberry has long been established to suppress UTI infection and the Pomegranate is touted as an anti-cancer superfood by many. Can't hurt as a daily ritual, and there is also the placebo effect.
